text:
down areas at Telfer Mine was advanced significantly during the year.   
 During the 2005 reporting period activities over the Deserts Revenge group of tenements included 
 an extensive review of near mine tenements in conjunction with a Paterson Province scale regional 
 study, plus ongoing construction and maintenance of waste dumps, tailings storage facility, water 
 management and infrastructure construction. 
 Gold and copper geochemical anomalism within the Deserts Revenge Group tenements remains a 
 potential  ore  source  for  the  Telfer  Project.  This  geochemical  anomalism  contains  high  arsenic-
 cobalt, typical of Telfer and ongoing metallurgical studies at Telfer are apportioned to this tenement 
 group.

text:
TENEMENT STATUS 
 The  Deserts  Revenge  Group  of  Mining  Leases  are  located  within  ground  originally  held  under 
 TR5653H; a Temporary Reserve designated for regional exploration by Newmont Holdings Pty Ltd 
 (NHPL), after the discovery of Telfer.  Following the discovery of auriferous quartz veins in 1973, 
 Mineral  Claims  were  pegged  across  the  area.    These  Mineral  Claims  were  surrendered  on  18th 
 December 1982, when EL 45/36, covering an area of 119.5 square kilometres, was granted for gold 
 and base metal exploration. 
 Pursuant  to  provisions  of  Section  65(1)(A)  of  the  Mining  Act  1978-1984  (W.A.),  Newmont 
 Holdings Pty Ltd was required to surrender at least half of the original area of EL 45/36 prior to 
 18th December 1985.  The first part of this surrender occurred in September 1983, when 10 square 
 kilometres were surrendered, concurrent with the pegging of ML 45/33.  The tenement was granted 
 as from 22nd August 1984, and is now reported on separately.  On 29th October 1985, a second 
 Partial  Surrender  of  EL  45/36  took  place  when  62.56  square  kilometres  was  surrendered  with  a 
 simultaneous application for nine (9) Mining Leases.  The Deserts Revenge Mining Leases 45/205, 
 45/206, 45/207 and 45/208 and the O’Callaghans Prospects ML 45/203  and 45/204 were part of 
 those applications. 
 Mining  Leases  45/203-8  were  granted  to  Newmont  Holdings  Proprietary  Limited  on  the  3rd 
 February  1986.    Further  Partial  Surrender  of  950.2  hectares  of  EL  45/36  took  place  when  ML 
 45/249 was applied for on the 1st December 1986 and granted on the 8th May 1987. 
 Work on these prospects prior to 1st  February  1986, has been included in the Annual Technical 
 Reports for EL 45/36. In 1987, the reporting of these tenements was completed as two groups. 
 O’Callaghans Group ML’s 45/203 and 45/204. 
 Deserts Revenge Group ML’s 45/205-208 and 45/249. 
 Since 1992, due to the locality of these mining leases, they have been reported on as one (1) group 
 and have come under the heading of the Deserts Revenge Group. 
 In  November  1994,  ML’s  45/632  and  45/633  were  pegged  as  a  result  of  the  compulsory  50% 
 reduction of EL 45/1070.  These tenements formed part of the Parallel Range Group of tenements 
 from that time and as such have been reported under that group.  Exploration control of the two

15.text: •  Stratigraphical and petrological studies have shown that Malu Formation host strata plays a

16.text: significant role in hosting most of the known mines and prospects within the Telfer district,

17.text: and similarly Broadhurst Formation strata hosts Nifty-style mineralisation.

19.text: folding, doming, and monocline development, occurred early in the orogenic history of the

text:
•  Stratigraphical and petrological studies have shown that Malu Formation host strata plays a 
 significant role in hosting most of the known mines and prospects within the Telfer district, 
 and similarly Broadhurst Formation strata hosts Nifty-style mineralisation.   
 •  Evidence  shows  that  structural  preparation  of  the  Yeneena  Basin  sediments,  including 
 folding, doming, and monocline development, occurred early in the orogenic history of the

20.text: Paterson  Province.  This  structural  setting  was  then  reactivated  during  a  later  Paterson

21.text: Orogenic event coinciding with introduction of granites and gold-copper mineralisation.

22.text: •  Studies suggest that, given their regional distribution in the area, granite intrusives are the

23.text: most probable heat source to drive broad-scale metasomatic alteration and mineralisation.

24.text: •  Available age constraints suggest that mineralisation developed in the Telfer region at ~600

25.text: Ma. This coincides with the emplacement of the last known phase of granitoid intrusions in

26.text: the region, which are relatively reduced, ilmenite-series monzogranites and syenogranites.

27.text: •  Petrological  studies  have  identified  five  distinct  hydrothermal  vein  and  alteration  phases

28.text: within  the  Telfer  system.  The  results  also  clearly  demonstrate  that  the  ore  fluids,  which

29.text: mineralized  the  Telfer  Dome,  possibly  derived  the  bulk  of  their  chemical  constituents,

30.text: including sulphur, and in all likelihood the metals from sulphidic carbonaceous black shale

32.text: •  Modelling of regional LAG geochemical data confirms a close spatial relationship between

33.text: early  generation  Miles Orogenic  fold  patterns,  centred  over  the  Telfer  region,  Telfer  host

34.text: strata, and distribution of reduced, ilmenite-series monzogranites and syenogranites.

38.text: The Deserts Revenge Group of tenements is located within the Mesoproterozoic to Neoproterozoic

39.text: Yeneena Basin. The Yeneena Basin consists of a succession of calcareous, pelitic and argillaceous

40.text: siltstones,  sandstones  and  carbonate  cover  sequence  sediments.  These  sequences  of  low-grade

41.text: metasedimentary rocks are known as the Yeneena Supergroup, which unconformably on-lap onto

42.text: the Palaeoproterozoic Rudall Complex to the southwest of Telfer.

43.text: The  Deserts  Revenge  and  adjoining  Parallel  Range  Group  of  tenements  comprise  Puntapunta

44.text: Formation and Malu Formation carbonate and arenaceous rocks and the southwest tenements are

45.text: located along strike to known gold-copper mineralisation at Pit 13 within the Fallows Field mining

text:
Paterson  Province.  This  structural  setting  was  then  reactivated  during  a  later  Paterson 
 Orogenic event coinciding with introduction of granites and gold-copper mineralisation.  
 •  Studies suggest that, given their regional distribution in the area, granite intrusives are the 
 most probable heat source to drive broad-scale metasomatic alteration and mineralisation.  
 •  Available age constraints suggest that mineralisation developed in the Telfer region at ~600 
 Ma. This coincides with the emplacement of the last known phase of granitoid intrusions in 
 the region, which are relatively reduced, ilmenite-series monzogranites and syenogranites.  
 •  Petrological  studies  have  identified  five  distinct  hydrothermal  vein  and  alteration  phases 
 within  the  Telfer  system.  The  results  also  clearly  demonstrate  that  the  ore  fluids,  which 
 mineralized  the  Telfer  Dome,  possibly  derived  the  bulk  of  their  chemical  constituents, 
 including sulphur, and in all likelihood the metals from sulphidic carbonaceous black shale 
 host rocks.  
 •  Modelling of regional LAG geochemical data confirms a close spatial relationship between 
 early  generation  Miles Orogenic  fold  patterns,  centred  over  the  Telfer  region,  Telfer  host 
 strata, and distribution of reduced, ilmenite-series monzogranites and syenogranites.  
 LOCAL GEOLOGY 
 The Deserts Revenge Group of tenements is located within the Mesoproterozoic to Neoproterozoic 
 Yeneena Basin. The Yeneena Basin consists of a succession of calcareous, pelitic and argillaceous 
 siltstones,  sandstones  and  carbonate  cover  sequence  sediments.  These  sequences  of  low-grade 
 metasedimentary rocks are known as the Yeneena Supergroup, which unconformably on-lap onto 
 the Palaeoproterozoic Rudall Complex to the southwest of Telfer. 
 The  Deserts  Revenge  and  adjoining  Parallel  Range  Group  of  tenements  comprise  Puntapunta 
 Formation and Malu Formation carbonate and arenaceous rocks and the southwest tenements are 
 located along strike to known gold-copper mineralisation at Pit 13 within the Fallows Field mining 
 lease (Figure 5.1).

23.text: bearing phases at Telfer Mine. Microprobing of pyrite grains confirms that, within these minerals

text:
6.  METALURGICAL STUDIES  
 To improve confidence in the predicted recovery of arsenic and cobalt from the Telfer Reserve ore 
 zones, analytical and metallurgical test work is currently in progress. Test work includes: 
 •  Bulk linear analysis and microprobing of selected concentrate samples. 
 •  Heavy  mineral  separation,  bulk  linear  analysis  and  microprobing  of  composited  drillhole 
 samples from Main Dome, Telfer Deeps, and West Dome. 
 •  Metallurgical testwork on Telfer Deeps composited bulk samples. 
 Preliminary studies confirm that both cobaltite and pyrite are the most abundant arsenic and cobalt-
 bearing phases at Telfer Mine. Microprobing of pyrite grains confirms that, within these minerals 
 arsenic and cobalt occurs in solid solution or as sub-microscopic particles.   
 This testwork is critical in understanding the mineral characteristics and deportment of arsenic and 
 cobalt in relation to concentrates produced at the new Telfer mill. The resource potential within the 
 Deserts Revenge Group is dependant on the outcome of these test results.  
 SITE SERVICES AND UTILITIES 
 The Deserts Revenge Group tenements, lying immediately southeast of the Mine Group tenements 
 are included in the construction requirements for present and future mine developments.  The focus 
 of  activity  associated  with  the  Deserts  Revenge  Group  of  tenements  during  the  2005  reporting 
 period  included  maintenance  of  services  and  utilities  associated  with  the  development,  and 
 operation of the Telfer Project. These are apportioned to this tenement group as part of the overall 
 present and future project development.   
 7.1  WATER SUPPLY 
 No  new  water  bores  were  drilled  within  the  tenement  areas  during  the  2005  reporting  period.

the fulfillment of the requirements of Ministerial Condition 606 (Western Australian Minister for 
 the  Environment  and  Heritage,  Ministerial  Statement  000606)  for  the  Telfer  project,  several 
 environmental  management  plans  specific  to  both  Telfer  Mine  and  near  mine  lease  areas  were 
 updated and implemented during the reporting period. The Subterranean Fauna Management Plan 
 (Newcrest internal report TP-PRO-80-02-0001) in particular was ongoing, with the first sampling 
 occurring in November 2004.  
 No regional exploration activity was carried out over the Deserts Revenge Group tenement areas 
 during the 2005 reporting period. 
 A review of drillhole rehabilitation policy was carried out by the Telfer Technical Services group, 
 with all future drillholes to be capped and plugged, and site rehabilitation completed in accordance

30.text: The  following  work  program  for  2006  is  recommended  to  test  the  significance  of  geochemical

31.text: anomalism shown in Figures 5.2 and Figure 5.3:

33.text: 1.  Considering the complexity of folding and extent of sand cover associated with the Montana

34.text: copper-cobalt  geochemical  anomaly  an  MMI  geochemical  survey  is  recommended  to  test

35.text: the potential location and depth extension of these specific mineralisation targets.

36.text: 2.  Based  on  outcomes  of  the  MMI  geochemical  survey  a  limited  program  of  RAB  or  RC

37.text: drilling  is  recommended  over  the  Montana  Prospect  to  test  for  primary  copper-gold

38.text: mineralisation below the known surface anomalism.

power station, anfo shed, and raw water borefield. 
 The  following  work  program  for  2006  is  recommended  to  test  the  significance  of  geochemical 
 anomalism shown in Figures 5.2 and Figure 5.3: 
 1.  Considering the complexity of folding and extent of sand cover associated with the Montana 
 copper-cobalt  geochemical  anomaly  an  MMI  geochemical  survey  is  recommended  to  test 
 the potential location and depth extension of these specific mineralisation targets.  
 2.  Based  on  outcomes  of  the  MMI  geochemical  survey  a  limited  program  of  RAB  or  RC 
 drilling  is  recommended  over  the  Montana  Prospect  to  test  for  primary  copper-gold 
 mineralisation below the known surface anomalism.
